Fig. 1 Thermal catalysis mechanism in a complete darkness: (a) Schematic diagram of the surface electron transfer mechanism for degradation of organic pollutants under dark environmental conditions (b) Schematic diagram of the hopping conduction mechanism in the thermal catalytic degradation of organic pollutants (c) A diagrammatic diagram of the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism in the thermocatalytic the decomposition of organic pollutants (d) A schematic representation of free radical chain autoxidation of organic pollutants in the dark without the addition of external oxidants or additional energy input (Copyright 2023, Elsevier, Ref. 3) [3]. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Scheme of Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. M–[O2−]–M: oxygen vacancy with active oxygen; M–[]–M: oxygen vacancy; M: perovskite-type oxide. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Photocorrosion reaction on metastable NaBiO3(NBO) nanosheets increases the production of singlet oxygen in lattice oxygen in NBO [9]; (b) Illustration of the formation of bismuth silver oxide (BSO) and its degradation of RhB dyes by generating singly linear oxygen as the main active species (Copyright 2023, Elsevier, Ref. 9). Lattice oxygen is increasingly attracting the attention of researchers as an active site in metal oxide catalysts. This paper reviews the strategies used in recent years to regulate the activity of lattice oxygen in catalysts and its application in catalytic reactions. It begins by exploring the mechanisms of lattice oxygen in various reactions, then provides a systematic overview of techniques employed to enhance the activity of catalysts, such as inactive A-site cation substitution, B-site cation substitution, the design of shell-core structures, and post-treatment of existing catalysts. Finally, the practical applications of these methods are discussed, including electrocatalytic reactions, advanced oxidation processes, and removal of volatile organic compounds. This review provides technical guidance for lattice oxygen-based metal oxide catalysts in oxygen vacancy modulation and provides a reference for future researchers interested in exploring the transformation of lattice oxygen in the reaction. Graphical Abstract The article reviews the mechanism of lattice oxygen involvement in the reaction, the activity regulation strategy and the application. ga1 Keywords Lattice oxygen activation Reaction mechanism Activity modulation strategy Oxygen vacancy Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Metal oxide catalysts play an important role in numerous processes, including CO oxidation, electrocatalytic hydrogen production, selective catalytic reduction of NOx, elimination of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), etc. So far, researches on the catalytic active sites of metal oxides have focused on their defective sites, such as oxygen vacancies, defective generated Lewis acid-base sites and metastable structures of metal cations. In recent years, lattice oxygen on the surface of metal oxides has emerged as active species in catalytic reactions. The involvement of lattice oxygen in redox reactions provides a different pathway for the catalytic process as compared to that occurring at defective sites in metal oxides. The bulk phase oxygen that forms the crystal structure is called lattice oxygen, which is frequently described in thermal oxidative catalysis (i.e., Mars van Krevelen mechanism) and battery cathode material design applications [1,2]. The application of thermocatalysis is focused on the treatment of non-degradable organic pollutants from wastewater, the removal of volatile organic pollutants from the atmosphere and the synthesis of gas phase products. Thermocatalysis and multiphase catalysis reactions occurring under dark conditions follow the same steps, with the five steps being the diffusion of reactants onto the catalyst surface, the adsorption of reactants onto the catalyst surface, the catalytic reaction at the catalyst surface, the desorption of products from the catalyst surface and the diffusion of products from the interfacial region into the host solution [3]. Depending on the fourth step of the reaction process, mechanisms of thermocatalytic reaction under dark conditions can be classified into the following four mechanisms, named surface electron-transfer mechanism, Hopping conduction mechanism, Mars-van Krevelen mechanisms (MVK), and Free radical chain autoxidation process, as shown in Fig. 1a-d. Among these mechanisms, MVK mechanism involves lattice oxygen oxidation and describes the catalytic oxidation process of VOCs. In summary, the mechanism reveals that it is the lattice oxygen in the catalyst, rather than the oxygen in the gas phase, which reacts with VOCs in two steps. The reactants first react with the lattice oxygen in the catalyst, leading to the depletion of the lattice oxygen to produce oxygen vacancies, which can be described as the reduction of the catalyst (Step 1); The oxygen vacancies in the catalyst are then replenished by the gas phase oxygen, leading to the regeneration of the lattice oxygen, a step that can be described as re-oxidation of the catalyst (Step 2). In addition to thermocatalysis, a review of efficient oxygen evolution reaction electrocatalysts involving lattice oxygen redox from both crystal and electronic viewpoints has also been summarized in detail. OER electrocatalysts typically follow the absorbate evolution mechanism (AEM), which consists of four concerted proton-electron transfer (CPET) reactions. However, this mechanism strongly correlates oxygen intermediate binding energies to activity, exhibiting a theoretical overpotential limitation of 370 mV [4]. Researchers are currently working to improve the efficiency of OER, and it has been found that the lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) can accelerate the direct coupling of lattice oxygen. It can minimize the limiting energy barrier and provide new ideas for the development of high-performance OER electrocatalysts [5]. The lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) to improve the rate of OER will be described in detail below. So far, redox reactions involving lattice oxygen have shown great potential in the field of electrochemistry and thermocatalysis, and some research results have been achieved. Although this process has attracted extensive attention from researchers, there is still a need for a specific review article that will systematically explain the underlying principles and list the most recent developments regarding this significant and timely subject. To this end, we aim to provide researchers in the field of electrochemistry and thermocatalysis with a comprehensive summary on modulating lattice oxygen activity and thus improving reaction efficiency. In this review, we first present the relevant mechanisms involving lattice oxygen in electrocatalytic OER reactions, advanced oxidation, and gas-phase reactions. Subsequently, the lattice oxygen activity modulation strategies were summarized. Finally, the current prospects for different applications of lattice oxygen activation are presented. 2 Mechanism of lattice oxygen participating in the reaction 2.1 MVK mechanism of thermocatalysis oxidation of VOCs A two-step redox reaction model is called the Mars-Van Krevelen Model (MVK), which was always used to explain the oxidation reaction rates of transition metal oxide catalyst. The MVK mechanism involving the participation of lattice oxygen in the reaction lies in the following process in the gas-phase catalytic reactions. The VOC first reacts with lattice oxygen to form CO2 or CO and H2O(g), followed by the activation of O2 molecules through the process of B(n+1)+ -site ↔ the Bn+ -site to generate reactive oxygen [6], as shown in the Fig. 2. The MVK model divides the VOCs oxidation process into two steps. The catalyst is reduced as a result of the initial reaction between the reactant and the lattice oxygen in the catalyst, which consumes the lattice oxygen and creates oxygen vacancies (Step 1). The vacant positions are filled with oxygen, which leads to the regeneration of lattice oxygen and the re-oxidation of the catalyst (Step 2). The MVK mechanism involves the catalyst being first reduced and later oxidized, hence it is also called redox mechanism. In steady-state operation, the rates of the reduction and oxidation steps must be equal [7]. The model has been widely used to complete oxidation of hydrocarbons over metal oxide catalysts [8]. It has been reported that lattice oxygen in the catalyst can be activated to accompany the reduction of higher valence metals in the catalyst to form reactive oxygen and oxygen vacancies, triggering the successive formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as hydroxyl radical (•OH), superoxide anion(O2 •−) and singlet oxygen (1O2) [9,10], as shown in Fig. 3a and b. The Mars-van Krevelem mechanism is associated with the lattice oxygen reaction process, in which a large amount of oxygen migrates towards the surface of the catalyst, becomes more available for oxidation of volatile organic compounds, and is replaced by gaseous O2 [11]. Metal oxides, according to Zhang et al. [12] can change oxidation states and thus participate in redox cycles. As a result, lattice oxygen (Olat) is regarded as a good indicator of catalytic performance in oxidation processes. According to related research, catalysts with more lattice oxygen have higher activity [13]. 2.2 Electrochemical lattice oxygen-mediated mechanism (LOM) In electrocatalysis, the conversion of sustainable energy into hydrogen by the hydrolysis of water has been widely used, as is shown in Fig. 4a. The OER half reaction is the bottleneck for total water splitting efficiency because of the slow kinetics of OER and the normally high overpotentials needed to tune on them. Despite the encouraging achievements of the AEM mechanism followed by OER, it is difficult for electrocatalysts to exceed theoretical overpotential to further increase the activity. Fig. 4b and c depicts the mechanism of AEM and the scaling relation between *OOH and *OH binding energies on various transition metal oxides. Recently, researchers have proposed another advanced mechanism for oxygen evolution cycles to bypass the intrinsic barrier of overpotential in AEM. Following a lattice oxygen-mediated (LOM) mechanism, oxygen ligands are electrochemically activated and liberated from the lattice matrix in this route. In this mechanism, lattice oxygen participates in the process of water oxidation by oxidizing itself to form oxygen molecules. The O 2p band must therefore be moved upward to approach the Fermi level (EF) in order to cause LOM. This will increase its orbital overlap with the d band (M-O bond covalency) of the metal and make the redox of lattice oxygen energetically attractive [14–16]. Lattice oxygen activation, which is a precondition for properly activating the LOM route, calls for the catalyst hosts to have a distinct electronic structure, particularly for the lattice oxygen itself. Recent findings classify the OER pathway through the LOM according to the different active centers (Fig. 4d-f) [17–20]. The lattice oxygen is first activated and then acts as an active site that receives OH- directly through nucleophilic attack, forming *OOH species. The gaseous product O2 is released to produce an oxygen vacancy site that is filled again by OH-. This mechanism is known as the oxygen-vacancy-site mechanism (OVSM, Fig. 4d) [19]. In a different process, the deprotonation step is followed by the catalytic center for OH- adsorption at a single metal site. This mechanism is called single-metal-site mechanism (SMSM in Fig. 4e). The direct coupling of the *O intermediate to the active lattice oxygen, which is energetically advantageous for higher-priced metal cations, is how SMSM and OVSM vary from one another. The created *OO species can be thought of as a freshly created O2 molecule for subsequently creating oxygen. The created *OO species can be thought of as a freshly created O2 molecule for subsequently creating oxygen [17]. In addition to these two single active centers, another way of LOM is the bimetallic site mechanism (DMSM), where a M-OO-M motif is anticipated to be formed by the intramolecular oxygen coupling of nearby activated lattice oxygen. (Fig. 4f) [18]. The specific process can be described as a transition metal ligand (MX), which consists of an anti-bonded MX* state (denoted as the d-band), a non-bonded pure ligand X state (denoted as the p-band) and a bonded MX state. When the cation d-band enters the p-band of the ligand, it can form ligand holes by transferring electrons to the metal, which is then reduced. Ligand cavities can be stabilized by changing the oxygen environment and forming O-O bonds, where the *OO* portion formed usually acts as a perovskite-like substance. 2.3 Mechanism of lattice oxygen activation in advanced oxidation During the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), organic matter can be oxidized to be H2O and CO2 by ROS with high oxidation ability, such as hydroxyl radical (•OH), sulfate radical (SO4 •−) and singlet oxygen (1O2) [22]. AOPs include thermocatalysis in dark ambient environments [3]. The five steps of thermocatalysis are as follows [23], transferring reactants from the liquid phase to the catalyst surface (Step 1), adsorbing reactants on the catalyst surface (Step 2), catalyzing reactions taking place in the adsorbed phase (Step 3), separating the product from the catalyst surface (Step 4) and transferring the product from the interfacial region to the solution (Step 5). According to previous literatures, thermocatalysis mechanisms under dark environment conditions can be classified into four categories: (1) Surface electron-transfer mechanism, (2) Hopping conduction mechanism, (3) Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, and (4) Free radical chain autoxidation process. Among them, the one involving lattice oxygen oxidation is the MVK mechanism. The MVK mechanism of lattice oxygen in thermocatalysis under dark ambient conditions has two steps [3]. The first stage is the improved lattice oxygen mobility on the catalyst surface, where the lattice oxygen oxidizes the impurities and reduces some of the catalyst. The reduced catalyst is then re-oxidized by the oxygen adsorbed on the surface. The lattice oxygen within the catalyst is activated to form reactive oxygen species (O*) and oxygen vacancies, which further promotes the formation of ROS (e.g., 1O2, O2 •−, and OH-) during the degradation process (Step 2) [9,10,24]. The oxygen vacancies increase and act as active sites for the adsorption of oxygen, which in turn forms lattice oxygen again. The rate-determining phase in this process is thought to be oxygen transfer between the catalyst and the contaminant. The re-oxidation of the reducing catalyst in the MVK process is essential for the stability of the catalyst. The MVK mechanism diagram can be interpreted in terms of the reactions involved in Fig. 5a taken oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane over chloride catalysts as the example [25]. Ethane was dehydrogenated by oxidation using a catalyst made of molten chloride bases that were combined together and supported by magnesium oxide that was doped with Dy2O3. The oxidation of Cl- on the surface of magnesium oxide results in the formation of the reactive oxyanionic OCl- species (Fig. 5b). Under reaction conditions, O2 regenerates this site by initially dissolving in the melt of alkali chloride, which dissociates and replenishes the oxygen vacancies on the magnesium oxide in a second step. 3 Strategies for regulating activity of lattice oxygen Related studies have shown that catalysts with more lattice oxygen have a higher activity [13]. To successfully activate lattice oxygen in catalysts so that it can participate in the reaction, current methods were developed, including modulating the cation, electronic structure and crystal structure of the catalyst. However, there is no literature that provides a sound categorical summary of such content. Therefore, in this literature, activation strategies for lattice oxygen in perovskite materials, pyrochlore ruthenates, spinel oxides and shell-core materials are summarized in four main categories of approaches, including (i) A-site ion substitution, (ii) B-site ion substitution, (iii) design of shell-core structures and (iv) post-treatment of catalyst. 3.1 Non-active A-site cationic substitution 3.1.1 Perovskite oxide Perovskite oxides are complex metal oxides with the structural formula ABO3, in which the B-site can be a divalent or trivalent transition cation with a small ionic radius, coordinated with six oxygen atoms. The A-site cation is typically a rare earth metal or an alkaline earth metal with twelve oxygen atoms, as shown in Fig. 6a [26]. The perovskite-type oxides are versatile for many catalytic reactions including those of the partial and complete oxidation of hydrocarbons. Also, with their novel electronic structure and abundance of defects, they are an efficient and important material for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), water splitting, and rechargeable metal-air battery applications [27]. Furthermore, the structure and physicochemical properties of the perovskite can be adjusted by changing their elemental composition and cation/anion stoichiometry, which gives them a diverse nature [28–30]. It was discovered that the catalytic activity of perovskites is influenced by both lattice oxygen and surface adsorbed oxygen. Surface adsorbed oxygen plays a significant role in oxidation at lower temperatures, and the B-position metal determines how effective it is. In contrast, the oxygen in the lattice plays a part at higher temperatures. The quantity and activity of lattice oxygen can be modified by altering the metal components at the A and B sites. In addition, partial substitution of A- and B-site ions with heterovalent cations can also produce lattice defects or lattice oxygen, and thus improve the catalytic activity. The most recent developments in heteroatom doping of perovskite oxides are listed in Table 1. The doping types are classified according to the class of doping positions in the ABO3-type perovskite oxide structure, including A-site doping, B-site doping, O-site doping, and double-site doping. The catalytic properties of perovskite oxide can be regulated by partial or complete cation substitution [52]. According to reports, the perovskite ABO3 structure is stable for over 90% of the natural metallic elements in the periodic table. As a result, the A or B cations in perovskite oxide can be substituted with different metallic elements to adjust their catalytic capabilities [53–55]. In order to maintain the desired perovskite oxide structure, a suitable replacement candidate should have similar ionic radii within the Goldschmidt tolerance factor t. The tolerance factor (t) in perovskite lattice follows the relationship as follows: (1) t = ( r A + r B ) / 2 ( r B + r O ) where rA, rB and rO are the ionic radii of the A-site, B-site and oxygen ion respectively. Various parameters influence the substitution, including the type and concentration of doping atoms and the substitution site. One advantage of perovskite oxides is the flexibility to adopt various metallic elements at the A- or B- site [56]. Since the transition metal ions at the B-site can interact with gas molecules (reactants and intermediates) via a series of d orbitals, it is generally accepted that these ions are catalytically active. It is known, however, that the aliovalent substitution at the A-site may significantly increase the catalytic activity of the perovskite through the mechanisms of altering the electronic state of the B-site cations and/or introducing oxygen vacancies [57]. The elements in A site have an important influence on the structure and stability of the perovskite oxide. According to the general formula A1−xA'xBO3 [58], the A-site metal is partially replaced by another metal A', which may lead to changes in the lattice vacancies and the valence of the B-site cations in perovskite [59,60]. For instance, Mefford et al. substituted the lower valence Sr2+ ion for La3+ to study the calixarene La1−xSrxCoO3-δ (0 ≤x ≤ 1). When lower-valence Sr2+ replaces La3+, the concentration of oxygen vacancies increases subsequently [17]. The embedding of oxygen in LSCO was studied using cyclic voltammetry to gain a better understanding of the role of oxygen vacancies in La1−xSrxCoO3-δ electrochemical applications. The insertion and removal of oxygen ions are shown as redox peaks in Fig. 6c. The increase in oxygen vacancy concentration increases the tendency for oxygen embedding. Due to the correlation between vacancy and Sr content, it can be assumed that the diffusion rate of lattice oxygen is proportional to the concentration of Sr. The diffusion rate of oxygen ions in LSCO was measured chronoamperometrically, and the results are represented in Fig. 6c. The catalytic activity of LSCO on OER was found to be closely related to the oxygen diffusion rate and vacancy concentration, as shown in Fig. 6d. As the oxidation state of Co increases, the d orbitals of the Co ion overlap more partially with the s and p orbitals of O2-, resulting in the formation of π* and σ* energy bands, as shown in Fig. 6b. When the overlap is large enough to form ligand vacancies (oxygen vacancies), the 3d π* energy band of the metal is no longer considered to be energetically isolated from the oxygen O 2p π* energy band. The Fermi energy can be modulated by applying a potential to the hetero-Co 3d-O 2p π* band, thus offering the possibility of lattice oxygen redox activity. By substituting cations of various valences and ionic sizes on both the A and B sites, ABO3 perovskites can be systematically regulated [61–63]. But the relative merits of π* antibonding versus σ* antibonding orbitals of d-electron symmetry, the degree of metal d and oxygen 2p orbital mixing at the active sites, the separation of the surface oxygens, and the pH dependence of the catalytic activity have been little explored. Li et al. [64] changed Sr2+ to Ca2+ with different electronegativity and ionic size from it, thus improving the activity of SrCoO3 cubic perovskite. The Rietveld refined powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of high-pressure ACoO3 (A = Ca, Sr) are shown in Fig. 6e. The consistent and well-crystallized structure of the surface and bulk of ACoO3 is confirmed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Fig. 6f). The high-pressure synthesis stabilized the CoIV ion in the intermediate spin state configuration t4σ*1 (Fig. 6g), where the d-wave symmetric σ* antibonding orbital is mobile, while the d-wave symmetric π* antibonding orbital is localized in SrCoO3 and crosses over with the mobile behavior in CaCoO3. In addition, CaCoO3 has a shorter Co-O bond length and a larger σ* bandwidth compared to SrCoO3 (Fig. 6g), increasing the mobility of Co 3d electrons and accelerating electron transfer. More importantly, the shorter separation of surface oxygen in CaCoO3 contributes to the direct coupling of lattice oxygen to form peroxide ion (O2)2- compared to SrCoO3, enhancing activity and durability. In particular, the authors compared the onset potential and OER activity of CaCoO3 relative to SrCoO3, Co3O4, LaCoO3, and RuO2 in O2-saturated KOH with varying pH (Fig. 6h). The two perovskites have comparable onset potentials, however CaCoO3 exhibits significantly stronger OER activity than SrCoO3. 3.1.2 Pyrochlore ruthenate oxides Pyrochlore ruthenate oxides has a general structural formula of A2B2O7-δ (A is usually a rare earth or alkaline earth metal and B is a transition metal) and is currently used as bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts among a variety of metal oxides for achieving both high ORR and OER activities [66]. It is shown that metal substitution can modulate the activity of pyrochlore ruthenate oxides. The A-site substituent can control the concentration of surface oxygen vacancy in the material, and the result of Density Function Theory (DFT) calculations indicates that excellent OER activity was related to the increase in oxygen vacancy concentration. Denis A et al. used a moderate level of A-site substitution to prepare Y1.8M0.2Ru2O7-δ (M = Cu, Co, Ni, Fe, Y) materials to study their OER activity and the structures are shown in Fig. 7a, where it was found that the activity could be controlled by the A-site cation. Fig. 7b confirms the successful doping of the M substituent into the pyrochlore structure and the homogeneous distribution of metals in the material [67]. Density functional theory calculations indicate that Y1.8M0.2Ru2O7 is substituted by Cu at the A-site, bringing the Fermi energy level (EF) closer to the O 2p energy band center. The lowering of the EF energy level, the increase in Ru-O bond covalency (Fig. 7c), and the rise of the O 2p energy band center favor the oxygen vacancy concentration VO (as shown in Fig. 7d). Eventually, the OER reactivity increases. This finding can be applied to the rational design of new compositions for oxygen electrocatalysis and other uses of lattice oxygen sites. Pyrochlore ruthenate oxides Y2Ru2O7 have been proved to be effective acidic OER catalysts with high catalytic activity and durability [67,69,70]. However, due to Coulomb interactions, Y2Ru2O7 exhibits typical Mott insulator behavior, which severely hinders the charge transfer between the catalytic site and the adsorbate [71]. Zhang et al. [72] partially replaced Y3+ in Y2Ru2O7 with Sr2+. This A-site substitution increased the bond angle of Ru-O-Ru, which improved the coordination geometry and alleviated the RuO6 octahedral distortion. It also controls the charge states of the Ru cation and oxygen anion through charge compensation, thereby attenuating the electronic association of the Ru tetrahedral band. Ru-O covalency is improved, Ru 4d electron correlation is mitigated, and catalytic activity is improved. Coordinated geometrical modulation and redistribution of electrons through Sr2+ substitution weakens the electronic correlation in the Ru 4d energy band, allowing Ru 4d electrons to leave the domain through the insulator-to-metal transition. The band rearrangement and induced Ru-O covalent promotion lower the charge transfer energy and quicken the interfacial charge transfer kinetics. At the same time, the energy barrier of the overall OER reaction is lowered as a result of the weakening of the metal-oxygen bonding strength. 3.2 Substitution of catalytic active B-site cation 3.2.1 Single perovskite oxide Although A-site cation substitution can be a modest strategy for controlling the activity of the catalyst. On the B-site transition metal center with catalytic activity, it only has a secondary impact. The difference is that manipulation of the catalytically active B-site cations provides a means of directly guiding the electronic states of the solid transition metal oxide host. Therefore, by selecting the B-site metal element and designing its oxidation state, it can be used to tune the covalent and hybridization of the metal 3d and O 2p states [73]. Because of the ionic-covalent hybrid nature of the metal-oxygen bond in perovskites [74], the metal 3d orbitals and O 2p states have similar energies and spatial overlap. Among many materials, ABO3-type single perovskites are regarded as promising OER electrocatalysts due to their low cost, flexible crystal structure, rich composition, surface defects, and tunable lattice. The OER activity of such perovskite crystals can be enhanced by tuning the defects, crystal, or electronic structure. The role of perovskites as OER catalysts is mainly influenced by the formation of BO6 octahedra at the b-site cation-catalyzed active sites, which are usually transition metals, especially 3d transition metal elements with different valence and spin states [75]. The interaction between the 3d and oxygen 2p states of transition metals has received much attention as a potential phenomenon in the properties of many transition metal oxides (TMOs) [19,76,77]. Shao and colleagues proposed that the catalytic activity of the catalyst could be enhanced by improving the covalency between the perovskite B-site and the O anion [63]. The higher the covalency between the B-site and oxygen, the greater the O-2p property possessed by the B-site, facilitating the charge transfer between the surface cation and the adsorbate [78]. Related literature has shown that loading noble metals on the surface of perovskite oxide carriers can yield excellent catalytic activity. Because the enhanced metal-carrier interaction produces more active sites, it is easier to obtain active O2 2- species [79,80]. Similarly, Dai et al. [68] created the ruthenium-substituted perovskites, SrCo0.9Ru0.1O3-δ. In Fig. 7e, the tetragonal superstructure of SrCo0.9Ru0.1O3-δ with a double cell along the c-axis is shown schematically. The unique super-exchange interaction between neighboring high-spin Co3+ and Ru5+ ions within the perovskite was found by XPS and XAS analysis (Fig. 7f). This super exchange interaction increases the active sites of the catalyst such as Co3+/Co4+, Ru5+, and O2 2-/O-, enhancing the electrical conductivity and metal–oxygen covalency. The increased metal-oxygen covalency helps to trigger lattice oxygen oxidation, thereby improving the lattice oxygen redox [73]. However, the activation of oxygen species in noble metal-free perovskite is a current challenge. By modifying SrCoO3-δ with Si, Pan et al. created catalysts with varying oxygen diffusivity and oxygen vacancy concentrations [44]. The obtained silicon-incorporated strontium cobaltite perovskite samples had similar properties of surface transition metal. It has been reported that a small amount of silicon (Si) doping causes a structural change in the catalyst, which significantly increases the conductivity of oxide ion and the diffusion rate of oxygen ions, and changes the concentration of oxygen vacancy [45,81]. A schematic diagram of this tetragonal structure is shown in Fig. 7g. It was observed experimentally that Si enters the perovskite framework in the form of a quadruple coordination with oxygen (i.e. SiO4 4- orthosilicate). This leads to the creation of oxygen vacancies, a decrease in the oxidation state of Co, an increase in the covalency of the Co-O bond, the production of more reactive oxygen species, and an increase in lattice oxygen activity, thus improving the OER activity of the catalyst. 3.2.2 Ruddlesden-popper perovskites Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites are a structure consisting of perovskite-like layers (ABO3) and alternating rock-salt layers (AO), which can be described by the formula of An+1BnO3n+1 (n = 1, 2 and 3) ( Fig. 8a) [82]. Lately, their roles as OER electrocatalysts have received increasing attention since they possess higher intrinsic activity than their simple perovskite counterparts [83]. The direct interstitial mechanism (rock salt layer) and the vacancy mechanism of diffusion (perovskites layer) are the two processes that are currently used in practically all discussions and studies on oxygen ion diffusion mechanisms in the Ruddlesden-Popper series [85]. Numerous experimental studies have demonstrated that the oxygen exchange rate on the surface of Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites is largely dependent on the presence of oxygen vacancies in the perovskite layer. Increased activity is aided by the high concentration of interstitial oxygen in the alternating rock-salt layer and highly reactive lattice oxygen in the perovskite layer [86–88]. Many Ruddlesden-Popper perovskites have undergone doping with various metal ions, and the radius and valence of the doped metal ions control the crystal structure. Ding et al. [87] synthesized Co3+-doped RP-type materials La1.5Sr0.5CoxNi1−xO4 with x = 0, 0.2, 0.5, 0.7 and 1 using the sol-gel method. The bond energy of the B-O bond is the primary limiting factor for lattice oxygen in the perovskite-like layers, where the catalytic ability of lattice oxygen is nearly entirely dependent on the quick removal and relocation of O2-. The length of the Co-O bond in the CoO6 octahedra is longer than that of the Ni-O bond in the NiO6 octahedra. The longer Co-O band and larger ionic space means that the covalent bond Co-O has a lower breaking energy than Ni-O, then CoO6 octahedra have a higher lattice oxygen mobility than NiO6 octahedra. In addition, the doping of Cox+ at the Niy+ site has a high B-site valence, which facilitates the increase of interstitial O2- concentration and lattice oxygen activity [86]. The redox reaction of the lattice oxygen is increased, and the catalyst activity is increased. In addition, it is shown that the order of Ruddlesden-Popper can be increased by ion doping, thus improving its catalytic activity. This is because the higher-order RP phase possesses an abundant concentration of readily depleted oxygen vacancies and stronger metal-carrier interactions than the lower-order Ruddlesden-Popper. Dama et al. [84] prepared Ni3+ substituted Ruddlesden-Popper layered oxides Srn+1Tin-xNixO3n+1 by a citrate gel method to study their catalytic activity during methane reforming. It was found that oxygen is released from the surface oxygen vacancies during the reaction when the temperature is raised in a programmed manner. The O2-TPD profiles for the Ruddlesden Popper (RP) phase of Srn+1Tin-xNixO3n+1 (n = 1, 2, 3 and ∞) are shown in Fig. 8d. With the decrease in metal ions from the high-valent to the low-valent state, a portion of the bulk lattice oxygen evolves as well. Transient pulse experiments show that carbon species formed on the high-order Ruddlesden-Popper phase are eliminated by reaction with surface oxygen (Fig. 8b and c). Therefore, the high-order Ruddlesden-Popper phase produced by B-site cationic substitution has higher reactivity and stability. 3.2.3 Spinel oxides In addition to perovskite, researchers have found that spinel oxides can also enhance catalytic activity through B-site cationic substitution. Spinel-type catalysts have higher stability in the catalytic oxidation process compared to mixed metal oxides and perovskites [89]. The basic structural formula of spinel is AB2O4, where A refers to Cd, Ni, Mn, Ca, Ba, Li, Cu, Ge, Zn, Fe, Mg, Co, etc. and B refers to Fe, Cr, Al, Ni, Mo, Ga, Mn, Co, In, etc. In Fig. 9a, the structure of spinel oxide is depicted, with A controlling the tetrahedral positions and B controlling the octahedral positions. Normally, tetrahedral interstices (A-site) often have smaller sizes than octahedral interstices (B-site). Thus, smaller cations tend to occupy the A site, while larger cations tend to occupy the B site [90]. Spinel oxides are stable and flexible, allowing the incorporation of many metal ions with variable valences [91]. Zhang et al. [60] studied the ZnCo2−xNixO4 series of spinel. It was found that when Co3+ was partially replaced by the more electronegative Ni metal cation, the remaining Co3+ will lose electrons, and the energy of the antibonding states will decrease. That is, electrons are drawn away from the remaining Co3+ and the energy of the antibonding state is reduced, triggering a redistribution of electron density between the metal cation and the oxygen, and thus altering the electrocatalytic properties [92]. In ZnCo2−xNixO4, the p-band center of oxygen is higher than the d-band center of MOh for x ≥ 0.4, and the energy difference is larger with increasing Ni substitution ratios, according to first-principles DFT+U calculations for the two states. The energy of the O state is lower in spinels with x = 0 and 0.2 than that of MOh, indicating that oxygen is tightly bonded to the cation and that lattice oxygen is redox inactive under oxidizing circumstances. As x continuously increase to 0.4, the energy of the O state is higher than that of the MOh state, and thus oxygen ions become redox active. However, as their energies are still relatively close, the whole lattice structure remains stable. And as x increases further to 0.6 and above, the energy of the O state is greater than that of the MOh state, and the lattice oxygen activity of the material also increases (Fig. 9b). It is demonstrated that cation substitution can be used to tune the OER process and produce OER catalysts that are extremely active and metastable. It has been shown that partial substitution of metals can lead to more structural defects and faster oxygen migration rates [93]. Due to its rapid electron transfer, good reducibility, simplicity of synthesis, and structural stability, Co3O4 is regarded as a promising catalyst for the oxidation of VOCs [94]. Co3O4 has a spinel structure (AB2O4) with a cubic dense lattice arrangement of O2-, with Co2+ at the tetrahedral center (A-site) and Co3+ at the octahedral center (B-site) [95]. The oxidation state of Mn is switchable, with a similar ionic radii to Co, and is usually doped into the spinel-like Co3O4 to enhance the catalytic oxidation of VOCs [96]. During the reaction process, the adsorbed VOCs first react with surface lattice oxygen to form CO2 and H2O, and then the adsorbed oxygen or native lattice oxygen replenishes the consumed surface lattice oxygen. This is consistent with the MVK mechanism [97]. Ye et al. [98] prepared a series of mesoporous hollow Mn-substituted Co3O4 catalysts using a modified solvo-thermal alcoholysis method. Experimental results showed that the substitution of Mn reduced the grain size of the microspheres, increased the specific surface area and improved the homogeneity of the microspheres. The surface exposure of additional active sites (defects and lattice oxygen) was increased by the small defective microcrystals of Mn-substituted Co3O4 and expedited the adsorption and conversion of reactants. However, there are drawbacks to the interaction of Co with Mn, including decreased reducibility, diminished lattice oxygen mobility, and the reduction in surface Co3+ and adsorbed oxygen dispersion. 3.3 Preparation of catalysts with core-shell structure Core-shell nanoparticles are an emerging class of nanostructured materials that have attracted widespread interest in recent years for magnetic, electronic, catalytic, optical, and medical applications. Core-shell nanomaterials are widely defined as the cores and shells of different substances that interact closely, including inorganic/organic, organic/organic, inorganic/inorganic, or inorganic/biological combinations [99]. The oxidation shell in shell-core-structured catalysts can regulate the supply of lattice oxygen to the active site. The product distribution of alkane oxidative dehydrogenation is strongly influenced by lattice oxygen activity and will be helped by design of the shell-core structure [100,101]. In a typical core-shell design, 3d transition metal oxides are often designated as the core, which is less active due to its ease of sintering. Depending on the design, the shell can provide a variety of functions, including (i) a high melting point shell to provide resistance to sintering [102,103], (ii) a redox active oxide shell to regulate oxygen supply [104], (iii) a catalytically active shell to complement the chemical activity of the nucleus [105,106], and (iv) a low melting point shell where the shell layer forms a molten layer during high temperature operation to facilitate oxygen transfer and catalysis [90,107]. Types (ii) and (iv) are the most pertinent in terms of controlling lattice oxygen activity. Yin et al. [104] created core-shell structured Fe@Ce oxygen carriers for the steam methane reforming reaction in the chemical cycle. Fig. 10b shows the TEM morphological images and elemental distribution of Fe@Ce oxygen carriers, demonstrating that Fe@Ce particles have a core-shell structure, where the Fe-based nanocore is covered by a cerium-containing shell, and that this structure remains constant throughout the test. The oxygen carriers have a cerium dioxide shell covered with iron oxide nanonuclei, combining the advantages of high electrical conductivity of cerium dioxide ions and strong propensity to store oxygen of iron oxide. Fig. 10a depicts the process for chemical looping steam methane reforming with a shell and core structured oxygen carrier. It is shown that the CeO2 shell can speed up the movement of lattice oxygen between the surface of the shell and the iron oxide nanonuclei. In addition, with the redox cycle, Fe cations migrate outward from the nanocore to the surface of the core-shell particle. This increases the phase proportion of CeFeO3 with a perovskite structure and enhances the transport of oxygen ions from the native to the surface of the core-shell oxygen carriers. This further improves CO selectivity, methane conversion, and catalyst reactivity. Redox-active shells are typically applied to methane chemical cycle steam methane reforming. Moreover, in addition to the traditional sense of the core-shell structure, some researchers have prepared redox catalysts by covering the surface of perovskite oxides with molten shells. The chemical chain of oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane was studied. Gao et al. [107] prepared redox catalyst consisting of solid La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 substrate and molten Li2CO3 layer. The molten layer promotes the formation of active peroxides (O2 2-) on the La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 while blocking the nonselective sites. In the working state, Li2CO3 forms a molten layer over a solid La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 (LSF) substrate as the catalyst for redox. The molten layer both regulates the lattice oxygen activity and facilitates the rapid transport of ions through the shell layer. During CL-ODH of ethane at 700 °C, the molten Li2CO3 shell layer converts the lattice oxygen in La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 to O2 2-, which is considered to be highly selective for ethylene. La0.8Sr0.2FeO3 bodies are re-oxidized by the formed peroxides. Also, the peroxides replenish the active lattice oxygen species in the catalyst. Fig. 10c depicts the chemical pathways for the ODH and reoxidation processes. 3.4 Post-treatment of catalysts The amount of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst affects the activity of the lattice oxygen [108]. Normally, oxygen vacancies will arise spontaneously with the creation of cationic defects to maintain charge neutrality. This defect feature facilitates the migration, emission, and intercalation of the lattice oxygen [107,109]. To control the concentration of oxygen vacancies, a post-treatment method can be used [109]. For instance, Liu et al. prepared mesoporous Mn-Co spinel oxides with tunable oxygen vacancies by the solid-state grinding method with the addition of vitamin C [108]. The findings demonstrated that adding vitamin C efficiently raised the amount of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst. Meanwhile, the strength of the Mn-O bond near the oxygen vacancies was weakened. Thus, the activity of the lattice oxygen was improved. Based on the above theory, post-treatment options for existing catalysts are summarized in this section with the aim of increasing the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst and improving the activity of the lattice oxygen and the catalytic reaction efficiency. 3.4.1 Gaseous thermal treatment The introduction of oxygen vacancies in the transition metal oxides can enhance the adsorption of oxygen and the migration activity of lattice oxygen, thus improving the catalytic performance of transition metal oxides. By annealing in an oxygen-deficient environment at an appropriate temperature, oxygen vacancies can be produced [110]. The formation process of oxygen vacancies can be described by the following equation [111]. (2) Oo ↔ MOs Vo + 1 2 O 2 + 2 e It is possible to represent the concentration of oxygen vacancies as a function of oxygen PO2 pressure. (3) C Vo = K n − 2 P O 2 − 1 2 Where Oo, Vo, Cvo and Po2 denote lattice oxygen, oxygen vacancy, the concentration of oxygen vacancy and oxygen pressure, respectively. From the above equation, it can be seen that oxygen vacancy concentration and the pressure of oxygen are inversely proportional, therefore annealing under oxygen deficient conditions helps the formation of oxygen vacancies in metal oxides. The most popular method to create oxygen vacancies is heat treatment in a hydrogen atmosphere. Therefore, hydrogenation method is widely used to form oxygen-deficient metal oxides [112–114]. Because electrical conductivity and redox activity work together synergistically in electrocatalysis, hydride (H-) ions have the potential to become electrochemical and catalytic materials. For example, Toriumi et al. converted the cubic perovskite oxide BaZr0.5In(III)0.5O2.75 into the highly anion-deficient oxyhydroxide BaZr0.5In(II)0.5O2.25H0.5 by annealing it at 800 °C under hydrogen atmosphere ( Fig. 11a) [115]. The reduced perovskite phase is highly anoxic. H- entered to the center of the [100] face of BaZr0.5In(II)0.5O2.25H0.5 and formed oxygen vacancies after In(III) was reduced to In(II). In photocatalysis, the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the material was increased by hydrogenation treatment. This can be seen in conjunction with Fig. 11a and b. Upon exposure to H2, the weight of BZI decreases dramatically due to the loss of oxygen and stabilizes within 1 h. The cubic perovskite structure of the BZI sample has been maintained after heating at 800 °C in dry H2 for 12 h, according to X-ray diffraction (XRD). The photocurrent was enhanced, thus improving the stability of the material during water oxidation. Wang et al. [112] reduced W6+ to W5+ under high temperature hydrogen treatment, resulting in the synthesis of stoichiometric WO3−x with the introduced oxygen vacancies (Fig. 11c). And as compared to pristine WO3, the hydrogen-treated WO3−x had enhanced photocurrent density and good stability, with no significant loss of photoactivity for at least 7 h for the application of water oxidation. In addition to the reducing gas of H2, other oxygen-deficient atmospheres, such as CO, N2, Ar, and vacuum, were also used to investigate the conditions of high-temperature annealing to produce oxygen vacancies [114]. Likewise, Ling et al. [116] created hematite β-Fe2O3 by thermally decomposing β-FeOOH in an oxygen-deficient (N2 +air) atmosphere, and the resulting hematite samples were rich in oxygen vacancies. The formation of oxygen vacancies (Fe2+) leads to an increase in the density of electron donors, thus enhancing photoactivity (Fig. 11d). In order to prepare highly photoactive hematite for photoelectrochemical water oxidation without the need of dopants at a relatively low activation temperature, a straightforward and efficient approach is presented in this work. 3.4.2 Solid phase reduction Many solid powders have also been used as the reducing agents, by which the lattice oxygen atoms on the surface of metal oxides are consumed, leading to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies. For instance, Shi et al. [117] used a ball-milling assisted solid-state reaction approach to create oxygen-deficient Li4Ti5O12−x anode powder. Graphene oxide promotes the conversion of Ti(IV) to Ti(III) in Li4Ti5O12−x materials, accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies. The results of XPS and EPR showed the presence of Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies in the material. The prepared oxygen-deficient Li4Ti5O12−x shown remarkable electrochemical performance as demonstrated by a capacity of 172.4 mA h g-1 at 0.5 C and a capacity retention of 96.9% after 100 cycles. 3.4.3 Solution reaction Solution reaction techniques were created as an alternative to the above technique, which requires high temperatures, to create oxygen-deficient oxides. Solution reduction using sodium borohydride (NaBH4) is one of the most successful and popular practice to create oxygen vacancies in the metal oxides under mild circumstances. Zhuang et al. [118] used NaBH4 as a reducing agent to prepare iron-cobalt oxide nanosheets with a large specific surface area and abundant oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancies enhanced the electronic conductivity and provided more active sites for catalysis. In addition to using NaBH4 as a reducing agent, TiCl3 can also be used as a reducing agent. In addition, Liu et al. [119] controlled the content of oxygen vacancies in WO3 by adjusting the ratio of W5+/W6+ in proportion to the concentration of TiCl3 ( Fig. 12a). Different concentrations of TiCl3 solutions (50 ml, 100 ml, 150 ml, 200 ml) were prepared by dilution with HCl. WO3 was immersed in TiCl3 solution at room temperature and the prepared samples were noted as WO3-1, WO3-2, WO3-3, WO3-4. The original WO3 and the samples treated with HCl or TiCl4 were named as WO3-0, WO3-T. Fig. 12b shows the XPS pattern of the sample. c-f two distinct additional peaks can be seen, which are attributed to the existence of W5+, indicating the presence of oxygen vacancies in WO3-(1−4) [120–122]. It is shown that the certain concentration of oxygen vacancies could be used as shallow electron donors in WO3 films, but too high oxygen vacancy concentration would lead to a decrease in photocurrent [112]. Therefore, the concentration of TiCl3 can be adjusted during the synthesis process to control the concentration of oxygen vacancies, thus improving the performance of the catalyst. 3.4.4 Electrochemical method Electrochemical methods are of interest due to their short reaction times, simple equipment, and low cost to produce oxygen vacancies in metal oxides. The electrochemical anodic oxidation of metals and the electrochemical reduction of metal oxides are the two main electrochemically induced oxygen vacancy formation ways. Electrochemical anodization refers to the oxidation of a metal substrate in a specific electrochemical environment [125]. In the process of anodic oxidation, an oxidation reaction (M → Mn++ne-) occurs on the surface of metal at sufficient anodic voltage, and then Mn+ ions react almost immediately with O2 in the electrolyte to form a homogeneous oxide layer. It is an efficient method that allows some control of the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Hazra et al. [123] synthesized TiO2 nanotubes by electrochemical anodic oxidation in a mixed electrolyte containing selective aqueous NH4F and ethylene glycol. The study of the x-ray photoelectron spectra in Fig. 12c shows that there are several free oxygen vacancies present in the reduced TiO2 nanotubes as well as defective states connected to OVs and various suboxide states. It achieved the regulation of oxygen vacancies in the nanotube arrays by controlling the amount of H2O. The analysis of PL spectra (Fig. 12d) showed a significant increase in the amount of OVs in the case of TiO2 grown in an electrolyte having a lower H2O concentration. Electrochemical reduction is a simple, rapid, and highly scalable method that can produce oxygen vacancies in metal oxides [126–128]. Zhou et al. [127] used a cathodic reduction method to introduce oxygen vacancies into the TiO2 nanotube arrays. The modified TiO2, with highly improved electrochemical activity, possesses higher electrical conductivity and enhanced capacitance for supercapacitors application. Compared to traditional thermal treatment procedures, this technology greatly decreases the instrumentation and resource needs. 3.4.5 Plasma treatment Plasma treatment methods are regarded as effective methods for producing oxygen-deficient metal oxides [124,129], such as TiO2, α-Fe2O3 and Co3Ox (Fig. 12e). Under high-energy plasma, the lattice oxygen on the oxide surface is released in a short time while maintaining its morphology and structure. In addition, impurities can be avoided during the treatment process, which greatly simplifies the synthesis process and ensures the purity of the samples. Some degree of doping can also be seen when using hydrogen, argon, oxygen, and nitrogen plasmas. In addition to these plasma sources, air plasma has been reported as an effective method. The catalysts designed using the plasma-engraving strategy not only have a higher specific surface area but also generate more oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. As mentioned above, increasing the amount of oxygen vacancies not only improves the lattice oxygen reactivity of the catalyst by reducing the formation energy of oxygen vacancies, but also contributes to the adsorption and activation of O2 by significantly reducing the adsorption energy of O2. The catalyst activates molecular oxygen regeneration to form lattice oxygen, thus improving the cycling stability of the catalyst [130]. 4 Application of activation of lattice oxygen in catalytic reactions 4.1 Liquid-phase catalytic reaction 4.1.1 Electrocatalytic reaction The series of methods described above for modulating lattice oxygen activity is important to guide the synthesis of highly active and stable catalysts. These methods are often used in the synthesis of catalysts for liquid-phase and gas-phase catalytic reactions. The liquid-phase electrocatalysis aims to trigger lattice oxygen-mediated mechanisms to promote OER kinetics. The cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction are the two half-reactions that make up water splitting. The following equations can be used to describe it. (4) Cathodic : 2 H 2 O l + 2 e − → H 2 ( g ) + 2 OH − ( alkaline / neutral ) (5) 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 ( g ) ( acidic ) (6) Anodic : 4 OH − → O 2 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( l ) + 4 e − ( alkaline / neutral ) (7) 2 H 2 O ( l ) → O 2 ( g ) + 4 H + + 4 e − ( acidic ) (8) Overall : 2 H 2 O ( l ) → 2 H 2 ( g ) + O 2 ( g ) OER is a concerted proton–electron transfer reaction, which requires a large overpotential beyond its theoretical potential. Therefore, the OER kinetics is slow and becomes a rate-limiting process for the whole hydrolysis reaction [131]. There are currently two mechanisms for implementing OER cycle. One is the absorption evolution mechanism (AEM), in which oxygen precursors undergo a stepwise adsorption-deprotonation-coupling-desorption process, namely *OH→*O →*OOH→O2 [132,133]. The conventional AEM mechanism requires a considerable overpotential, which is usually difficult to achieve on the surface of electrocatalysts and thus making it difficult to further improve the activity of the catalysts. In a subsequent study, an alternative LOM mechanism for triggering lattice oxygen redox was proposed [134]. This solves the problem of the dynamic evolution of the surface of the catalyst, bypassing the obstacles inherent in AEM [17]. The recently put out LOM theory makes the assumption that the catalytic surface is no longer thermodynamically stable but yet permits dynamical changes to occur alongside oxygen evolution. The OER cycle depends on the lattice oxygen ligands on the catalyst surface being oxidized, exchanged, and released. For the excitation of LOM, activating lattice oxygen is crucial. This calls for the metal oxide catalyst to possess a distinctive electronic structure. Researchers are constantly working to find advanced solid-state OER electrocatalysts that meet the requirement of LOM [60,135,136]. Recent studies have shown that transition metal hydroxides can participate in the OER reaction as electrocatalysts through a lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism [137–140]. BiFe (oxy)hydroxides (BM/BiFeOxHy) with lattice vacancies was prepared by Jo et al., where the introduction of Fe increased the peroxy-like oxygen (O2 2-/O-) and the reactants of OER followed the LOM pathway to generate O2 [141]. The XPS spectra of the O 1 s region show metal-oxygen and oxygen-hydrogen bonds, representing lattice oxygen and hydroxyl groups on the BM/BiFeOxHy surface ( Fig. 13a). Also, it was verified that perovskite-like lattice oxygen species with localized holes (O2 2-/O-) exist close to the binding energy of 532.4 eV. On the electrocatalyst, the existence of such peroxo-like lattice oxygen species is anticipated to make the LOM process easier and increase OER activity. The lattice oxygen-associated OER pathway of BM/BiFeOxHy causes while metal-oxygen bonding decreases in the O 1 s region (Fig. 13b), the binding energy of peroxygen-like oxygen species (O2 2-/O-) increases and becomes dominant. After theoretical density functional theory (DFT) calculation (Fig. 13c), it is known that the lattice vacancies on BM/BiFeOxHy are associated with the decoupling of some proton-electron transfer steps of LOM, which greatly improves the electrode performance of OER. In addition, the amorphous structure of BM/BiFeOxHy enhances the diffusion of oxygen, Lattice vacancies and amorphous structure can work together to improve OER performance as a whole. In addition, lattice oxygen redox provides a new way to obtain superior electrochemical properties of rechargeable battery transition metal oxides (TMOs). Donggun Eum et al. [142] demonstrated a strong correlation between lattice oxygen oxidation and local structural changes during dynamic intercalation of TM-oxide-based electrodes by comparing two similar materials with significantly different oxygen oxidation activity and stability. It was observed by characterization that the contrasting electrochemistry of lattice oxygen in (Na0.6(Li0.2Mn0.8)O2 (NLMO) and (Na0.6(Li0.2Ti0.2Mn0.6)O2 (NLTMO) electrodes stems entirely from different TM migration pathways (that is, in-plane and out-of-plane cation migration, respectively). This cation migration eventually leads to the formation of short O-O dimers (<1.34 Å), which stabilize the oxygen network through the rearrangement of the electronic structure. More importantly, it was revealed that different cation migration paths in layered TMOs control the conversion kinetics of π to σ interactions (Fig. 13d). These findings provide guidance for the further development of oxygen redox layered electrode materials. 4.1.2 Advanced oxidation processes Advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) are crucial for wastewater remediation, since some persistent organic pollutants are difficult to be degraded by conventional method [143]. In this process, organic matter is oxidized to H2O and CO2 by the reactive oxygen species (ROS) with high oxidation capacities, such as hydroxyl (•OH), sulphate (SO4 •−) and singlet state oxygen (1O2) [144]. As •OH and SO4 •− are unstable in the complex aqueous environments due to the extreme pH value and the coexistence of anions, many researchers have increasingly focused on 1O2. 1O2 is the excited state of molecular oxygen, which is highly active as ROS during the treatment of pollutants [145,146]. There are various methods to generate 1O2, and the technology to generate 1O2 by activation of PMS has been widely developed. Peroxymonosulfate (PMS, HO–O–SO3 −) activation is a typical AOPs method. During the catalytic process in the presence of PMS, active species SO4 •-, •OH, singlet oxygen (1O2), and superoxide radical (O2 •-) were discovered [147]. Using oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen to activate PMS to create 1O2 is a more energy-efficient method than previous activation strategies [147–149]. For example, Cheng et al. [150] introduced Sr into the A site of perovskite LaFeO3 to modify its structure, and used it to activate PMS for degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid. The experimental results show that Sr doping leads to a low oxidation state of Fe and enhanced charge transfer from oxygen vacancies, and thus synergistically promotes the catalytic activity of La0.5Sr0.5FeO3 for PMS activation. In addition to the doping strategy, the formation of complexes can also promote the activation of PMS [151,152]. Similarly, Ma et al. [153] synthesized LaxNiO3 (LxNO, x = 1, 1.1, 1.15 and 1.2) with different levels of single perovskite/Ruddlesden–Popper layered perovskite interface for exploration. The results showed that L1.15NO exhibited the best catalytic activity, which is attributed to the abundance of active sites (lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancies) for ROS generation. In addition, the formation of nanocomposites rich in hetero-interfaces can also enhance the ability of lattice oxygen to participate in the process of 1O2 generation. The involvement of lattice oxygen in the generation of 1O2 during PMS activation was reasonably verified by interfacial engineering, with the following reaction equation (Eqs. 9–11). (9) M n + 1 + O 2 − → M n + + VO ∙ ∙ + 0.5 O 2 (10) VO ∙ ∙ → O * (11) O * + HSO 5 − → HSO 4 − + O 2 1 where VO••, O* and O2- represent oxygen vacancies in normal positions, reactive oxygen and lattice oxygen ions, respectively. Due to the lattice expansion, some lattice oxygen atoms are released to form reactive oxygen species, which favors the formation of oxygen vacancies; when PMS is dispersed in solution, reactive oxygen species prefer to generate 1O2 by electron transfer. 4.2 Gaseous phase catalytic reactions 4.2.1 Catalytic removal of VOCs Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) are a broad term for a class of carbon-containing organic molecules that can be evaporated at ambient temperature. The current methods for treating VOCs are adsorption, absorption, ozonation, biological degradation and so on [154,155]. Catalytic oxidation is a promising method due to its high elimination efficiency and environmental friendliness [156,157]. Metal oxides, including Co3O4, CuO, MnOx, TiO2, have been used as catalysts for the removal of VOCs [156]. In the case of catalytic oxidation, the mechanism of VOCs oxidation was discussed extensively in the previous literatures based on lattice oxygen (Mars−van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism) or adsorbed oxygen (Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L−H) mechanism) [158]. The former mechanism is governed by oxygen activation and bulk lattice oxygen movement [159]. Feng et al. [160] prepared Pt/Cu alloy catalysts and investigated the possible effect of oxygen species activation on the catalytic performance and the reaction pathway for the removal of VOCs. The results showed that the Pt/Cu alloy structure led to the alteration of the active oxygen species during the oxidation process of toluene. In addition to O2 adsorption, some of the active lattice oxygen species can be supplemented by lattice oxygen migration. With the increase of reaction temperature, the weakly adsorbed isohexane can react with the lattice oxygen in time, leading to the high catalytic stability of iso-hexane oxidation on Pt/Cu. The catalytic oxidation of VOCs by manganese oxide also follows the Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, where the lattice oxygen in the catalyst can participate in the oxidation of VOCs [161]. Sun et al. [162] showed that abundant lattice oxygen can provide excellent catalytic performance. Then, Fan et al. [163] used doping method to modify the properties of α-MnO2 nanorods. The doping of Fe affects the length of the metal-oxygen bond, the metal valence, and the change in the lattice structure. Experiments and Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were used to investigate the effect of Fe doping on the lattice structure of α-MnO2. Fig. 14a shows the geometric optimization model used for the DFT calculation and the absolute energy for each case. These four models represent the case where iron is embedded in the skeleton and oxygen vacancies are present. The results show that Fe doping into α-MnO2 leads to the lattice distortion, resulting in the elongation of the Mn-O bond length along the local z-direction and promotion of the activation of lattice oxygen to participate in the catalytic redox reaction. H2-TPR findings provide experimental support for lattice oxygen activation. (Fig. 14b). The energy for the generation of oxygen vacancy decreases after Fe doping. Additionally, it was noted that the presence of oxygen vacancies might increase the redox reaction activity of the lattice oxygen in the vicinity; therefore, the formation of oxygen vacancies facilitated the catalytic activity of the Fe-doped samples [164,165]. Moreover, α-MnO2 samples doped with Fe also showed higher catalytic activities in other catalytic processes for environmental remediation, such as selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and chlorobenzene oxidation processes [166]. In addition to manganese oxides, cobalt oxides, especially Co3O4 catalysts, are also highly active for VOC oxidation [167–169]. Therefore, Co3O4-based catalysts have received considerable attention again in recent years [170]. Akram et al. [171] prepared CeO2-Co3O4 composites aiming to improve the catalytic performance for the degradation of ethyl acetate at relatively low temperatures. According to the experimental findings, the addition of cobalt ions causes the CeO2 lattice to lose its charge balance and boosts the amount of bulk lattice oxygen that is available. These properties give Ce0.5Co0.5 an excellent catalytic activity. The interaction of lattice-mixed Co and Ce ions leads to the enrichment of lattice oxygen, which enables the degradation of ethyl acetate under low temperature. Based on the low-temperature degradation of VOCs, Wang et al. [172] improved the performance of catalysts for the low-temperature oxidation of toluene by adjusting the oxygen vacancies in cobalt-cerium oxides. A series of CoCe-x bimetallic catalysts with Co loadings of 1, 5, and 10 wt% were prepared and characterized using various technologies. The reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation over CeO2 and CoCe-5 catalysts is shown in Fig. 14d. The produced CoCe-x catalysts were more active at low temperatures than CeO2 (Fig. 14c). This is due to the close interaction between the Co3O4 and CeO2 phases promoted the redox cycle of Co3+/Co2+ and Ce4+/Ce3+, which led to the formation of more oxygen vacancies and thus increases migration rate of both surface adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen. The effective migration of surface adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen leads to the rapid breakage of the aromatic ring, which is the key step in the mineralization of toluene. This also leads to an excellent low-temperature catalytic activity of CoCe-5 samples for toluene oxidation. Among the methods for the conversion of VOCs, thermal catalysis involving noble metals or transition metal oxides has been extensively investigated [173–176]. In addition to this approach, semiconductor photocatalysis as a technology using sunlight has been shown to be promising for both water decomposition and environmental remediation [177,178]. Earlier reports have also shown that methane activation and oxidation can be performed even at room temperature and atmospheric pressure by photocatalysis [179,180]. The metal oxide/perovskite interface has been proved to be an effective composite catalyst for methane activation [103,181,182]. Yang et al. [183] prepared ZnO/La0.8Sr0.2CoO3 (ZnO/LSCO) materials by rational metal oxide/perovskite interface design for efficient solar-driven methane oxidation. The ZnO/LSCO epitaxial interface was constructed by combining Co3+, Sr2+ and La3+ in the planes of LSCO (−110) with O2- in the planes of ZnO (01−10) at the same time. This resulted in bifunctional catalyst with synergistic photocatalytic and photothermal catalytic effects with much higher activity than the interface-free catalyst. The generation and filling of oxygen vacancies by unpaired electrons is promoted by regulating the electron transfer between the Zn 3d-O 2p hybrid orbital in ZnO and the Co eg orbital in LSCO. Thus, the activity and mobility of the surface lattice oxygen in the material and the activity of methane oxidation are improved. Because the reversible electron transfer at the contact is promoted by the synergistic effect of photothermal and photocatalytic interactions, further facilitating the amount and corresponding rapid replenishment of surface-active lattice oxygen. 4.2.2 Syngas production In recent years, syngas production from VOCs has attracted considerable attention [184]. A variety of methods have been investigated for the production of syngas and hydrogen, with most of these requirements being met by methane reforming. In the reaction of chemical chain steam methane reforming (CL-SMR), a combination of methane and oxygen from various oxygen sources is reacted to produce synthesis gas and hydrogen. The reduced oxygen carrier is then oxidized by steam to replenish its lattice oxygen, resulting in hydrogen generation in the steam reactor. He et al. [185,186] prepared Sr-doped La1−xSrxFeO3 perovskite materials, where Sr2+ substitution for La3+ produces an electron imbalance in the perovskite structure, generating oxygen vacancies or an increase in the Fe3+ oxidation state to Fe4+/Fe5+ to maintain charge neutrality. The Sr substitution in La1−xSrxFeO3 perovskite changes the coordination environment and electron density of the oxygen anions, resulting in two effects on the lattice properties of the catalyst. The first is an increase in oxygen vacancies in the main body of the oxides, and the second is the creation of high valent B-site cation concentrations in the perovskite. The former promotes hydrocarbons being completely oxidized to CO2 and H2O, whereas the latter prefers only partially oxidizing them to CO and H2. The partial oxidation of methane to produce H2 and CO is facilitated by bulk lattice oxygen. Hence, the ratio of Ola/Oad (Ola and Oad stand for lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen species, respectively) can be used as a comparative standard for the performance of oxygen carriers during chemical chain reforming, in which it is desired that selective oxidation of CH4 to syngas via O2 in the lattice. In addition, Fig. 15b shows that 80% of the active lattice oxygen of the reduced La0.7Sr0.3FeO3 sample can be replenished within a time frame of 6 min. The results show that among the La1−xSrxFeO3-δ perovskite, La0.7Sr0.3FeO3-δ exhibits the best catalytic performance for CH4 conversion. This can be used as a criterion for the reactivity and selectivity of the oxygen carrier for CL-SMR because it produced a maximum Ola/Oad ratio of 3.64:1. Based on the XPS analysis and the gaseous products generated in the steam oxidation stage, a reaction mechanism model for the water splitting reaction was proposed, as shown in Fig. 15a. Here is a multi-step procedure that describes how water vapor oxidizes reduced perovskite. (12) H 2 O ( g ) → OH − + H + (13) 2 OH − → O 2 − + H 2 ( g ) (14) Fe bulk in the B − site of La 0.7 Sr 0.3 Fe O 3 − δ perovskite − 2 e → Fe 2 + (15) 2 Fe 2 + bulk in the B − site of La 0.7 Sr 0.3 Fe O 3 − δ perovskite − 2 e → 2 Fe 3 + (16) 2 H + + 2 e → H 2 ( g ) (17) La 0.7 Sr 0.3 Fe O 3 − δ + δ H 2 O ( g ) → La 0.7 Sr 0.3 Fe O 3 + δ H 2 ( g ) However, in the process of steam reforming, carbon deposition reduces the activity of the catalyst. Faced with such a problem, some researchers have found that the lattice oxygen in the catalyst can oxidize the coke precursors during the reaction [186–188]. Sekine et al. [189] revealed that catalyst with partial Sr substitution in Ni/La0.7Sr0.3AlO3-δ exhibited higher catalytic activity and lower carbon build-up in the steam reforming of toluene. The reason for this phenomenon is that the partial doping of Sr causes lattice distortion, which allows the carbon generated during the water vapor reforming of toluene to have a greater mobility in the oxidation of lattice oxygen (Fig. 15c). The imbalance in oxidation states between the La3+ and Sr2+ positions leads to an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies, reduces the activation energy for lattice oxygen migration, and accelerates the rate of lattice oxygen migration. This imbalance also allows lattice oxygen to react with the carbon deposited on the catalyst surface as a surface oxygen species, improving the redox capacity of the catalyst, its activity, stability and resistance to coking. The lattice oxygen reaction equation is listed as follows. (18) C 7 H 8 + 7 O lattice → 7 C O lattice + 4 H 2 , ∆ H 298 0 = − 824.18 kJ mol − 1 (19) C O lattice + H 2 O → C O lattice O + H 2 , ∆ H 298 0 = − 41.2 kJ mol − 1 5 Conclusion The involvement of lattice oxygen as an active substance in redox reactions provides a new pathway for catalytic processes. In order to fully exploit the potential of this emerging pathway, we present a comprehensive summary of the reaction mechanism, lattice oxygen activity modulation strategy, and application of lattice oxygen activation. In Section 2, we discuss the mechanisms involved in lattice oxygen in different reactions, mainly including the MVK mechanism for thermocatalytic oxidation of VOCs, the LOM mechanism for electrocatalytic OER, and the lattice oxygen activation mechanism in advanced oxidation. Our next focus of attention is on the catalyst itself. As far as catalyst tuning is concerned, it has been desired to increase the lattice oxygen activity in order to achieve better reaction activity. In terms of catalyst preparation, the main reported methods include non-active A-site cationic substitution, substitution of catalytic active B-site cation, and the preparation of catalysts with core-shell structure. Furthermore, some post-processing methods are utilized to adjust the current catalysts, leading to a rise in the concentration of oxygen vacancies in the catalysts and significantly enhancing lattice oxygen activity as a result. The application of lattice oxygen redox reactions is discussed in the last section of this review. The various methods mentioned in Section 3 have been used in electrocatalytic reactions, advanced oxidation techniques, VOC removal, and the production of syngas, greatly improving the efficiency of the reactions. Based on the current research results in this research area, we have conducted a comprehensive review in the hope that it will contribute to the overall understanding of researchers and generate wide interest in other scientific communities. The modulation strategies discussed above and the selected practical examples are very promising for the future development of high-performance catalysts to improve the efficiency of catalytic reactions. However, the study of lattice oxygen redox in catalysis is still facing some pressing technical challenges. Therefore, based on these challenges, we propose several ideas for future research: (1) Synthesis method of catalysts. Most of the currently proposed lattice oxygen oxidation catalysts are synthesized by solid-phase reaction with a single means of synthesis. Moreover, the large particle size and small specific surface area of the products obtained by this method are not conducive to the improvement of surface activity. Therefore it is particularly important to develop new synthesis methods, such as hydrothermal methods, electrodeposition, electrostatic spinning, etc. These nanotechnology methods are expected to synthesize solid-state catalysts with nanostructures. (2) On surface reconfiguration. The activation and exchange of lattice oxygen during the reaction brings the electrocatalyst to a sub-stable state thermodynamically. In the OER process, the catalytic process of metal oxides often involves catalyst surface reconstitution or element leaching. In general, the increased oxygen vacancies in chalcogenide oxides reduce material stability and may lead to cation leaching and surface amorphization, thus deactivating the electrocatalyst itself. This hinders the application in real life. Therefore, the development of highly stable electrocatalysts in electrocatalytic reactions is a necessary task for future research. (3) Further theoretical studies. For the chemical cyclization reaction mentioned above, an in-depth study of the role of lattice oxygen in the reaction and the theory is lacking. For partial oxidation reactions, the redox state of the metal oxide catalyst is an important factor in determining the activity and selectivity. In contrast, there is no clear explanation for the relationship between the nature of the oxygen vacancies involved and the electrophilicity of the lattice oxygen with the selectivity of partial and complete oxidation. In future research, improving the reversible oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst is the primary issue that must be addressed for the industrialization of the lattice oxygen selective oxidation process. coredata.dc:description: Lattice oxygen is increasingly attracting the attention of researchers as an active site in metal oxide catalysts. This paper reviews the strategies used in recent years to regulate the activity of lattice oxygen in catalysts and its application in catalytic reactions. It begins by exploring the mechanisms of lattice oxygen in various reactions, then provides a systematic overview of techniques employed to enhance the activity of catalysts, such as inactive A-site cation substitution, B-site cation substitution, the design of shell-core structures, and post-treatment of existing catalysts. Finally, the practical applications of these methods are discussed, including electrocatalytic reactions, advanced oxidation processes, and removal of volatile organic compounds. This review provides technical guidance for lattice oxygen-based metal oxide catalysts in oxygen vacancy modulation and provides a reference for future researchers interested in exploring the transformation of lattice oxygen in the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: A review of activating lattice oxygen of metal oxides for catalytic reactions: Reaction mechanisms, modulation strategies of activity and their practical applications
